awd_titl_txt: NSF Workshop on Seamless/Seamful  Human-Technology Interaction
awd_abstract_narration:
This project will hold a workshop and publish a report addressing seams, that is, significant junctures among people and technologies. Seams involve the ways that different modalities, mechanisms, and situations of interaction are connected. Researchers across fields will gather and collaborate to address and formulate emerging research questions. Where do seams arise? How can they be stitched together? How can consideration of seams enable developing new relationships among people and technologies? When do we want our interactions with technology to be seamless, that is, for the seams to be invisible to human participants? When might we want seamful design, which makes seams visible, reminding the humans of gaps? The workshop report will be published on the workshop website, and in prominent archival venues, such as through the ACM and IEEE. 

This workshop and report authoring will involve researchers across fields, including human-computer interaction, machine learning and data science, haptics, internet of things, wearables, computer graphics and computer vision, cognitive science, design, and computational creativity to consider seamless and seamful design addressing and combining: high-dimensional data analysis, computational creativity, interactive art, interaction design, exploration of machine learning model spaces, communication awareness, buildings and urban spaces, computational companions, and user modeling. Research contributions are expected to take forms such as ideas for new research initiatives, implications for design, frameworks, and theories.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Over the last decade, machines and our interactions with them have had a massive impact in our daily lives, from the way we search for and receive information, to the way our factories and distribution centers are run, to the way we interact with devices in our homes. With these interactions, it has become clearer that the traditional goal of building autonomous artificial intelligence (AI) systems is (in general) misguided: what we want instead are systems that we can control. Rather than have systems that replace us, we want systems that augment us. We want robotic arms that continue our declared motions, we want creativity support tools that are easy to use but that are flexible enough for our purposes, we want machine learning models we can understand and troubleshoot, and we want communication and language tools that help us better express ourselves. But when and how should we interact with such systems to be most effective? The answer to this question lies with our creation and elimination of “seams.” In some cases, we would like our interactions with AI to be simple and seamless, with a low barrier to entry (e.g., “Alexa/Siri, please dim the light”). In other cases, we would actually create seams, where human control is needed (e.g., “Should I really deny this person's loan application based on an AI prediction alone?'”). The questions of how and where to place or remove these seams leads to a new paradigm: that of Seamless/Seamful Human Computer Interaction.

In this workshop, we asked: What might Seamless/Seamful Human-Technology Interaction (SHTI) mean? Where are the important seams--the junctures between people and technology, between different modalities, mechanisms, and situations of interaction? How are these seams stitched together? How can we develop new (seamless) relationships between people and technologies? (When) do we want our interactions with technology to be seamless? When might we want to be reminded of the seams? SHTI research could involve people who currently work in many different fields, including human-computer interaction, multimodality, machine learning and data science, haptics, internet of things, wearables/tangible interfaces/ubiquitous computing, social impact of technologies, computer graphics and computer vision, visualization of data, personalization, cognitive science, and computational creativity. We also discussed opportunities in the space of SHTI, including future of work / work well-being, lifelong and pervasive learning, quality of life, reimagining technology’s relationship to society (correcting for previous oversights and mistakes), and education. Finally, we discussed considerations in SHTI interaction including ethics, privacy, potential harms, and evaluation of SHTI technologies.
